reviewText: The second part of an English spy story based on events post the "cold war" period in England. Sir Alec Guinness is asked by Brittish Intelegence after his retirement from that service, to "tidy up" some loose ends which he has special knowledge of. The head of Soviet Intelegence Smileys Russian counterpart becomes the the focus of George Smileys activities and through his previous knowledge of that individual and recovering "bits and pieces" from the past Intelegence efforts leads Smiley to achieve the down fall of the Soviet Spy master.Part One, Tinker Taylor Solder Spy, begins with a mole believed to be in the highest level of British Intelegence. A cat and mouse game that Is played out over the entire of Europe, the sub-content and the then powerful Soviet Union. George Smiley (Alec Guinness) a senior Intellegence Officer, now out of favor with the present management at the Intellegence headquarters is ask by senior members of the government to find the mole.
summary: A great English actor, a suspenseful English spy story.

reviewText: This is made for TV John le Carré work uses Alec Guinness as George Smiley.  I could never imagine anyone else as that character every time I reread those novels.  Guinness was one of a kind.  The price on this set and Tinker, Tailor both done with Guinness in the 1980's for BBC fluctuates.  I feel lucky to be able to periodically immerse my self in the Cold War and am always pleased by the experience.  If you enjoyed the books you will be pleased by Smiley's People.

reviewText: Watching this movie again after 30 years tends to make more sense then it did the first time.  Smiley is an old coot who just wants to catch one more snake.  Guiness is a fine actor and makes business with what ever he is up to.  The photography is wonderful with gorgeous shots.  But the costume designer is off the wall with those peculiar mod glasses on old Smiley...really strange looking.  Plus he keeps wearing different topcoats and never brings a suitcase when he goes to various cities to hold all his coats plus 2 kinds of hats.  When Smiley goes into the barbecuing house in Lubeck, he is wearing his green Loden coat but when he leaves the house he puts on a long black leather trench coat with a belt which is quite inappropriate for him but it does go  with his goofy glasses.  He walks out of the house but seems to forget that he has no transportation to the airport since he came in a cab which has long left; shades of Inspector Clouseau. And later when he returns to Paris he surfaces again with the green Loden coat and the long black leather trench coat at various times.  Made me quite dizzy keeping his hats and coats straight.

reviewText: The release of the new version of Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy in theaters encouraged me to see both the original 6-hour TV series with Alec Guiness (which I had seen before) and this sequel (which, for some reason, I had not).This is a worthy sequel to the other series. I would say it has a bit more action, it's another mystery story in a way but you don't even know what the mystery is! Excellent acting all around. An enjoyable way to spend one hour for six evenings (it's a six hour production). If you enjoyed the original series then you must see this one too.  DVD includes an interesting contemporary (post cold war) interview with John LeCarré, a different interview from the Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy DVD but one which was recorded at the same time.
summary: Excellent sequel to Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy

reviewText: It's probably safe to assume that anyone watching this BBC import miniseries has already seen -- and liked -- the classic "Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy." BBC's producers wisely recognized that the middle book of the series, "The Honorable Schoolboy," wasn't going to translate to the screen, so they went straight from the first story of the trilogy to the last. Comparisons between Smiley and Tinker Tailor are inescapable and it speaks well of the sequel that it is a worthy successor to the original."Smiley's People" maintains some of the main strengths of the original: Le Carre's taut characterization and plotting; excellent scripting, casting, and behind-the-camera work; and, most of all, Sir Alec Guinness's magnificent portrayal of the brilliant but profoundly flawed Cold Warrior George Smiley.In some respects, this series follows the arc of the first one: George Smiley again is in a rather unhappy and not-entirely-voluntary retirement, having been removed once again following his brief return as head of the Circus. And, like the original story, he is called back in to take on a delicate errand for the Circus. The premise of this one is a little different -- he's brought in officially, by the current head of the Circus, rather than being somewhat offline, sponsored out-of-channels by "Lacon and the Minister." And the errand initially seems somewhat trivial: cleaning up the somewhat disorderly murder of a long-ago Circus informant. Obviously, the story quickly builds into something much deeper.The plot probably isn't quite as compelling as the original, but then, "Tinker Tailor" was one of the best miniseries ever. This one takes a little longer to develop and some of the "visits" Smiley makes in his investigation (the obligatory visit to former research chief Connie, for example) seem more like sentimental visits than necessary parts of the investigation. The cast of "characters" Smiley encounters also seems a lot more miscellaneous than in the former show and some of the subplots (the Russian woman in Paris, for example) aren't that compelling.But it's a great yarn and a very satisfying ending to George Smiley's Cold War.I missed the steady presence of Peter Guillam in this series. The replacement character was far weaker and seemed much less "Guillam-ish" (the original Peter seemed a little more like a soccer thug who went to college, while the new Guillam seemed more like a croquet player). But he didn't appear until the very end and didn't really matter to the story.This loss is more than made up for by the greatly enhanced role for Toby Esterhaze, one of the great character roles I've ever seen.It's a great Cold War spy yarn and a very satisfying end to this saga.
summary: Not quite as good as "Tinker, Tailor," but still outstanding

reviewText: This was a rather odd final sequel to John LeCarre's cold war trilogy. It features George Smiley once again. But the story plays as if its more about Simley's age coming to an end than anything else. It oddly (and unintentionally) seems to be hinting to the end of the cold war era a decade early. Smiley always seems to be out of place throughout the story as are his "people"...the emigres that used to be the pawns used by the intelligence services of all sides. Everything looks tired and played out. The oddest scenes are where smiley goes out personally into the field as it were dealing with a corrupt club owner and german street trash. Its like people from two different eras are dealing with it each other.Even his arch-nemisis, the Soviet officer Karla, is no longer really playing the same game. Karla is more haunted by personal issues than he is playing the spy game. Patrick Stewart plays Karla perfectly and does it hardly saying a word. He creates menace just from looks and body language.The series is still an odd but interesting almost euleogy for the cold war and the spymasters who fought it mostly from old office buildings.

reviewText: Smiley's people is the sequel to Tinker, Tailor, Solider Spy. The spine-tinkling action continues when Smiley, former head of espionage for the British Secret Intelligence Service, has been forced into retirement along with Vladimir, the informant who used to work under him. When Vladimir gets caught up in a shoot out, Smiley is supposed to brush it under the table, but instead, he uses it as a way to get back into the game and hunt for his old anniversary, Karla, the soviet super spy.This was a spy film filled with intrigue and edge of your seat tension. I was excited to see Patrick Stewart enter the role of Karla. He adds a soft-spot to the hardcore spy who wants to bring his mentally ill daughter to the West for treatment. A unique and realistic look at the cold war with actors and settings that really bring it to life.***Complimentary copy received in exchange for an honest review***

reviewText: This is the sequel to the original Tinker Taylor Soldier Spy, it tells you about Mr. Smiley's return, to help out the British intelligence. Smileys part is play by Sir Alec Guinness who is marvelous. To understand the story it will help if you buy the first series Tinker Taylor Soldier Spy  not the film version but the series by the BBC and again featuring Sir Alex Guinness in the Part of Smiley. This story will round off the first series and has all the ingredients of a great thriller.Well worth the time to watch it and re watch it again. Enjoy and hopefully you will get as much fun from this series as I did. When the British really get the right people to write produce and act, you get this excellent thriller.  Watch both of these series, you will only enjoy them.
summary: Great cast great story, buy Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy first, the version with Alex Guinness which is far better than the film

reviewText: It is amazing that they tried. Even more amazing that they succeeded. It was a miracle seeing all these characters in flesh and blood. The talented cast gave JLC's novel the full respect it deserved (from Richard Burton to Gary Oldman, a constant commonality through his adaptations is the superb cast).Alec Guinness deserves all the gratitude from us for his willingness to incarnate George Smiley. On the DVD extras, JLC explains on an interview that Alec Guinness made Smiley so real that every time that he tried to work on Smiley after the series, all he saw was Alec Guinness. He gave up on the character.The rest of the cast also deserves the highest praise. I particularly enjoyed Bernard Hepton (Toby). Beryl Reid made a more believable Connie than in the book.I saw the BBC version of Tinker, Tailor a few years ago. Last year I saw the movie with Gary Oldman and I thought that Oldman had an edge. After watching "Smiley's People", I need to reevaluate. From what I remember of Oldman's performance, there is a lot of Alec Guinness there. It is as Guinness provided the base. The truth is that they are both virtuosos of the craft. That's not a competition.The DVD transfer is uneven. The colors and all the technical aspects of the series reminded me the movies that I used to watch in the 70s (even if the series is from 82).
summary: Read the book, watch the movie

reviewText: The Smiley novels (Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy; The Honourable Schoolboy; and Smiley's People) are among my favorites. I read them about every two years or so, and they do not lose their power to entertain. When I discovered that both Tinker Tailor and Smiley's People were available on DVD, I made the purchase immediately. Smiley's People continues George Smiley's pursuit of his Soviet counterpart and nemesis, Karla, who created such havoc in The Circus (as described in Tinker Tailor and The Honourable Schoolboy). Alec Guiness is absolutely perfect in the role of Smiley. Old, reserved, awkward and soft, just as Le Carre describes him. But also patient, persistent, and icy cold when the need arises. Guiness perfectly captures these varied characteristics. Of the two DVD sets, Tinker Tailor is the stronger. Smiley's People seems more dated somehow, more TVish. Where Tinker Tailor keeps you on edge, Smiley's People sometimes seems slow. Still, it is a good adaptation of the novel and well worth purchasing,if for no other reason than to watch Guiness positively nail Smiley. My only question is: where is the adaptation of The Honourable Schoolboy???)
Title: N/A

reviewText: It mystifies me that so many here are rating these two miniseries ("Tinker" and "Smiley's People") five stars.  Many years ago, I noticed them on PBS, and found them to be exceptionally slow-moving, numbingly cerebral and complex, bland, and ultimately disappointing. I don't need an explosion or car-chase every five minutes, but this was a meager meal, indeed.  As a matter of fact, I have come to view their type as a kind of touchstone of the mediocre in the spy genre.I will admit that reading the book versions beforehand (and riveting one's eyes to the screen) might have made a difference in my appreciation of these, but I was little impressed "back when," and don't think I'll invest any money in thrashing through the underbrush of the same old territory again.  And, there is so much better fare abroad, such as the "Bourne" series, "Salt,"....."Ronin," "The Good Shepherd,'..."The Manchurian Candidate" (both versions),..."The Recruit,"..."Spy Game,"..."Breach"..."Mission Impossible" (and some of the Bond pictures, such as "Quantum of Solace")...."Four Days of the Condor".."The Package"..."The Spy Who Came in from the Cold," "The Mechanic"...and the current TV series, "Homeland." These are like a full-course meal, compared to the water and hard-tack of the Alec Guinness vehicles, which are also a fine remedy for insomnia.

reviewText: Recommend not trying to bite this one off all at one time.  Watch an episode each night and saver each minute.  It is hard to follow at times (bless those English transitions) and deliciously convoluted.  I've watched Smiley's People over eight times over the years and am beginning to reinterpret everything!  I was stationed in France during the thick of the cold war, one year after"Check Point Charlie" was created.  I could related to Carla's crossing.  What fun for us "cold war" babies.
summary: Settle in for a long rainy weekend.

reviewText: It has been a long time since I have found such an enjoyable, rich, exquisitely complex story. Enjoyable in the fact that so much truth is expressed in the sorrow, insanity, paranoia and broken lives caused by insane, dominating leaders in any country.This story cannot be fully enjoyed unless one knows some of the important details of the book, which I have not read. Since many of the characters have more than one name and there are many important hidden meanings, one would miss too much of the depth of the characters, the history and the period.I would highly recommend one either read the book or a wiki synopsis then watch. The majority of the characters, if not all have so many layers. It also tells a story of an incredibly insane time - life in Stalin's Russia. With all the spying, invasion of privacy etc., people had to go through incredibly elaborate methods to communicate important information to each other.It's a story told from the point of view of a retired British spy named George Smiley and his journey in honoring the murder of a longtime Russian double agent, General Vladimir. Vladimir was attempting to get information to George about flushing out longtime enemy, KGB spymaster, Karla.It is such a richer story telling of the spy world than what is usually shown. Though lightly expressed, it does show the sorrows, paranoia, and insanity. Not to justify the need for spying as there are too many grotesque similarities in today's political world.There are so many incredible performances from many supporting actors, many who had just a few lines, a few scenes, but offer powerful and memorable performances: Otto Leipzig as Vladik Sheybal; Paul Herzberg as Villem Craven; Curd Jargens as General Vladimir. Each actors' performance moved the story ahead in powerful ways. Then there is Bill Paterson who plays the "new" cocky, rude, bad mannered, "know it all" spy, Lauder Strickland, I was repulsed. Bernard Hepton played Toby Esterhase in an enjoyable and enthusiastic way; Mario Adorf played Claus Kretzschmar brilliantly, warmly and sympathetically, though I hated the biased line written for him demeaning unions as the cause for Britain's monetary downfall. Joe Praml carried over his small role from Tinker Tailor brilliantly, keeping a strong presence in a role that had few lines and Jacques Maury played Sergei warmly.Spoiler alert: After all this build up about K.A.R.L.A., the ending was much more disappointing and anti-climatic then Tinker Tailor. It landed like a 20 ton lead balloon. After all the murders K.A.R.L.A. carried out on the Brit's and American spies from his moles, especially, the huge, long betrayal of Bill Hayden, when George gets K.A.R.L.A. to defect, promising that Brit taxpayers will pay for his daughter's hospitalization and care as well as his ~ as long as he cooperates with his interrogators, George arrives at the rendezvous point two hours early, because they "owe it to" K.A.R.L.A. and "no one else is on his side." W-H-A-T???? Did George suddenly forget the 300-400 or more spies K.A.R.L.A. had tortured and killed, often participating in the activities? Then K.A.R.L.A. finally crosses and George has to be strongly encouraged by Peter (wonderfully played by Michael Byrne) to look. W-H-A-T???? Then K.A.R.L.A. and George gaze into each others' eyes and K.A.R.L.A. drops the cigarette lighter, which George doesn't pick up. It's supposed to communicate some important insight, but the ending misses hugely and disappointingly. It still is well worth watching again and again for all the wonderful performances by the above mentioned supporting cast.There are a few big inconsistencies in the story, example, after George and Peter rescue Mrs. Ostrakova and are at Peter's flat in France, George exposes some secrets to Peter and then, worrying about Peter's place being bugged, says, "How long since you've had the ferrets in?" then writes KIROV's name on a piece of paper, not very discreet with all the other "secret" information he just gave away.Also, in Tinker Tailor, George had no children, but in Smiley's People, when talking to Mrs. Ostrakova, he says he has one daughter.I wonder how much of George Smiley's character is based on LeCarre's idea of himself while a spy. So many lines are written and said in Tinker Tailor and Smiley's People to over-emphasize how brilliant, well respected and important George is.
summary: An exquisite portrayal once you've read the book or a synopsis
